photo.description: The Colosseum in Rome, viewed from Via dei Fori Imperiali. Originally known as the Flavian Amphitheater, it was the largest building of the era. Emperor Vespasian started construction of the Colosseum in AD 72. It was completed in AD 80, the year after Vespasian's death. It was built on the site of an artificial lake, part of Nero's huge park in the center of Rome which also included the Colossus statue, a giant statue of Nero, that gave the building its current name.

photo.description: From <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiColosseum">Wikipedia<a>: The Colosseum or Coliseum, originally the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an elliptical amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy, the largest ever built in the Roman Empire. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Occupying a site just east of the Roman Forum, its construction started between 70 and 72 AD under the emperor Vespasian and was completed in 80 AD under Titus, with further modifications being made during Domitian's reign (81–96). The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. It remained in use for nearly 500 years with the last recorded games being held there as late as the 6th century. As well as the traditional gladiatorial games, many other public spectacles were held there, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The building eventually ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era. It was later reused for such varied purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry and a Christian shrine. <a href"http:bighugelabs.comflickronblack.php?id2362686268&amp;sizelarge">View On Black<a> <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworldpooltagsitaly">Back to Italy<a> - <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworld">Visit the World<a>

photo.description: At the Colosseum I spent quite a bit of time photographing the hypocaust, the area beneath the wooden arena floor, where there was a complex set of rooms and passageways for wild beasts and other provisions for staging the spectacles. A portion of the floor has now been rebuilt and occasionally plays are presented to modern audiences.

photo.description: &quot;The Colosseum or Flavian Amphitheater was begun by Vespasian, inaugurated by Titus in 80 A.D. and completed by Domitian. Located on marshy land between the Esquiline and Caelian Hills, it was the first permanent amphitheater to be built in Rome.&quot; - Great Buildings Online I liked taking this photo of the Colosseum because you don't see the traffic in front of it from this viewpoint Photographed in <a href"http:www.rome.info" rel"nofollow">Rome<a>, Italy.

photo.description: The Colosseum or Coliseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre (Latin: Amphitheatrum Flavium; Italian: Anfiteatro Flavio or Colosseo) is an elliptical amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy. Built of concrete and stone,[1] it was the largest amphitheatre of the Roman Empire, and is considered one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. It is the largest amphitheatre in the world.[2] The Colosseum is situated just east of the Roman Forum. Construction began under the emperor Vespasian in 70 AD,[3] and was completed in 80 AD under his successor and heir Titus.[4] Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96).[5] These three emperors are known as the Flavian dynasty, and the amphitheatre was named in Latin for its association with their family name (Flavius). photo.description: From <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiColosseum">Wikipedia<a>: The Colosseum or Coliseum, originally the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an elliptical amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy, the largest ever built in the Roman Empire. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Occupying a site just east of the Roman Forum, its construction started between 70 and 72 AD under the emperor Vespasian and was completed in 80 AD under Titus, with further modifications being made during Domitian's reign (81–96). The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. It remained in use for nearly 500 years with the last recorded games being held there as late as the 6th century. As well as the traditional gladiatorial games, many other public spectacles were held there, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The building eventually ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era. It was later reused for such varied purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry and a Christian shrine. <a href"http:bighugelabs.comflickronblack.php?id2369443775&amp;sizelarge">View On Black<a> <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworldpooltagsitaly">Back to Italy<a> - <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworld">Visit the World<a>

The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. photo.description: From <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiColosseum">Wikipedia<a>: The Colosseum or Coliseum, originally the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an elliptical amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy, the largest ever built in the Roman Empire. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Occupying a site just east of the Roman Forum, its construction started between 70 and 72 AD under the emperor Vespasian and was completed in 80 AD under Titus, with further modifications being made during Domitian's reign (81–96). The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. It remained in use for nearly 500 years with the last recorded games being held there as late as the 6th century. As well as the traditional gladiatorial games, many other public spectacles were held there, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The building eventually ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era. It was later reused for such varied purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry and a Christian shrine. <a href"http:bighugelabs.comflickronblack.php?id2363348833&amp;sizelarge">View On Black<a> <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworldpooltagsitaly">Back to Italy<a> - <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworld">Visit the World<a>

photo.description: Just after we entered into the Colosseum. We were using a Roma Pass, available for 25 euros, which gives free admission to two attractions, reduced admission to others, and free use of Rome's subways, buses, and light rail system. Best of all, the Roma Pass also has priority admission to all attractions. We were in the Colosseum in less than 2 minutes, as opposed to a hour and a half wait for those buying the tickets on the spot. The Roma Pass is a bargain. Part of a walking tour we did on our own using a couple of guide books from home. November 27, 2011

photo.description: PLEASE, no multi invitations, glitters or self promotion in your comments, THEY WILL BE DELETED. My photos are FREE for anyone to use, just give me credit and it would be nice if you let me know, thanks - NONE OF MY PICTURES ARE HDR. This is a view of the northwest side of the colosseum. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The city of El Djem was built, like almost all Roman settlements in Tunisia, on former Punic settlements. In a less arid climate than today's, Roman Thysdrus, now El Djem, it prospered especially in the 2nd century AD. The amphitheater was built here in the early 3rd century AD. This amphitheater could hold up to 35,000 people making it the third largest in the Roman Empire after the Colosseum in Rome and that at Capua (in ruins). Its 427m (1400ft) outside circumference is 100m (328ft) shorter than the Colosseum.

photo.description: I saw this from the bus heading to Olton. I later walked back over the Olton Acocks Green border to get shots of it. It is a restaurant called Colosseum. In June 2010, they were showing World Cup 2010 games. It used to be in the past: the Boundary Club and later Zorbas Greek Restaurant before becoming Colosseum. Decked out in England flags for the World Cup. Uploaded before England's match with Germany in the 2nd round. It is near Olton Boulevard East. England lost heavily to Germany 4-1. Out of the World Cup, again.

photo.description: The Colosseum in Rome. The subterranean structures, completed during Emperor Domitian (AD 81-96) were represented by rooms for gladiators and mechanical devices and cages for wild animals. The cages could be hoisted, enabling the animals to appear in the middle of the arena.

photo.title: Colosseum

photo.description: From <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiColosseum">Wikipedia<a>: The Colosseum or Coliseum, originally the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an elliptical amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy, the largest ever built in the Roman Empire. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Occupying a site just east of the Roman Forum, its construction started between 70 and 72 AD under the emperor Vespasian and was completed in 80 AD under Titus, with further modifications being made during Domitian's reign (81–96). The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. It remained in use for nearly 500 years with the last recorded games being held there as late as the 6th century. As well as the traditional gladiatorial games, many other public spectacles were held there, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The building eventually ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era. It was later reused for such varied purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry and a Christian shrine. <a href"http:bighugelabs.comflickronblack.php?id2361854469">View On Black<a> <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworldpooltagsitaly">Back to Italy<a> - <a href"http:www.flickr.comgroupsworld">Visit the World<a>

The name &quot;Amphitheatrum Flavium&quot; derives from both Vespasian's and Titus's family name (Flavius, from the gens Flavia). Originally capable of seating around 50,000 spectators, the Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. It remained in use for nearly 500 years with the last recorded games being held there as late as the 6th century. photo.description: Taken near the north side of the Colosseum as evening fell. This area is close to where the colossal statue of Nero is, and just across the street to the entrance of Rome's &quot;Colosseo&quot; MRT station. My last shot of the Colosseum, before taking the subway train. Lumina and Umbra are latin words, which translates to light and shade in English. I originally had the title of &quot;Light and Shade&quot; -- and just wanted to see something different. <b>The Colosseum - North Side Rome, Italy<b>

This is a view of the northeast side of the colosseum. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The city of El Djem was built, like almost all Roman settlements in Tunisia, on former Punic settlements. In a less arid climate than today's, Roman Thysdrus, now El Djem, it prospered especially in the 2nd century AD. The amphitheater was built here in the early 3rd century AD. This amphitheater could hold up to 35,000 people making it the third largest in the Roman Empire after the Colosseum in Rome and that at Capua (in ruins). Its 427m (1400ft) outside circumference is 100m (328ft) shorter than the Colosseum.

photo.description: Time to settle down a bit and send these from Rome. I think these trips are getting hectic, trying to go back to my list, and figuring out whom I missed out. I've already sent some, from Venice, Florence and Pisa. Sent some from within the walls of the Vatican. Now I'm checking who didn't get one yet. Its a little stressful, but sending out a postcard is a better souvenirgift than chocolates - they last forever, and besides, you don't have to carry it home. Of course, I only send to some to friends and relatives whose addresses I have kept. So if we're good friends, and you did not get one, you probably did not give me your address or your area's postal office is lousy. :-) <b>Postcards from Rome, Italy <b>

photo.title: Sending out some from Rome...

photo.description: And you marveled at the modern day stadiums -- its size and grandeur. Wait till you see this in person. This may not have the capacity, but -- does a stadium with a capacity of 50,000, with good acoustical design -- built almost 2,000 years ago (twenty centuries) amaze you? Built in the late 1st century AD, this huge stadium has a capacity of over 50,000. One of the most famous achievements of Roman engineering and an elegant work of Roman architecture. This elliptical amphitheater is known also as the Colosseu, Colosseum, Roman Coliseum, Flavian Amphitheater, Amphitheatrum Flavium, Anfiteatro Flavio. The manpower used to build it were from slaves and prisoners of the Roman Empire. Depending on which century you're looking at it, it was the site of great spectacle. It was used for dramas, executions, animal hunts, and other gatherings. In the early centuries, it was used many times to feed Christians to Lions and wild beasts. Time will soon change. When the Christian church rose to power, and adopted by the Roman Empire, Christian executions stopped -- and the Popes turned its power against those responsible for the scientific revolution. IN the early days of the medieval period, the Colosseum was predominantly used for religious activities and housing. And ironically enough, the stones and bricks used in the Colosseum -- where early Christians were executed -- were used in part to build the structures of Vatican City. <b>The Colosseum Rome, Italy<b>

photo.title: Colossal for Generations to Come...

photo.description: The man responsible for the greatest turning point of Early Christianity. In the year 312 AD, after winning a battle against another Emperor(at that time there were several emperors of Rome), he gradually led to the rise of Christianity. For years before that, Christians faced martyrdom, persecution and executions. Following Constantine's rule, Christianity rose to become the Roman Empire's official religion. Once you're walking the upper halls of the Colosseum, near the west side, you can have a good view of one of the largest arcs that the Romans built. The inscriptions read: IMP · CAES · FL · CONSTANTINO · MAXIMO · P · F · AVGUSTO · S · P · Q · R · QVOD · INSTINCTV · DIVINITATIS · MENTIS · MAGNITVDINE · CVM · EXERCITV · SVO · TAM · DE · TYRANNO · QVAM · DE · OMNI · EIVS · FACTIONE · VNO · TEMPORE · IVSTIS · REM-PVBLICAM · VLTVS · EST · ARMIS · ARCVM · TRIVMPHIS · INSIGNEM · DICAVIT In English: To the Emperor Caesar Flavius Constantinus, the greatest, pious, and blessed Augustus: because he, inspired by the divine, and by the greatness of his mind, has delivered the state from the tyrant and all of his followers at the same time, with his army and just force of arms, the Senate and People of Rome have dedicated this arch, decorated with triumphs. This arch had been here for around 1,700 years. And would later be a model for the creation of another great arc - in France - Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel - yes, that arc in front of the Louvre. Shot taken from the Colosseum's second level. <b>Arch of Constantine Rome, Italy<b>

photo.description: The underground prison, the dungeons, the viewing deck of the people of Rome, the Senators, the Emperors, the bloodbath, the massacre -- all that remains is this fearful symmetery. West side of the Colosseum, Shot taken from the east side. Note that the Colosseum is elliptical, with its major axis almost aligns from East to West. And I thought with the dull colors, I'll just have this in BW. <b>Colosseo Roma, Italia<b>
